In Table I, \$B_{fb}\$ is the size of the feedback message in units of bits, \$B_{\rm CSI}\$ is the number of bits used to deliver a user's CSI, \$B_{\rm ID}\$ is the number of bits used to deliver a user's identifier (ID), and \$P_{\rm fail}\$ is the probability of there being no successful feedback in \$\beta\$ minislots in [6].

If only user IDs are used in the feedback messages in [6] and in the proposed feedback protocol in the contention stage, the size of the feedback message is \$B_{fb} = B_{\rm ID}\$.

Hence, the feedback overhead in [6] becomes \$M_{t}(\beta B_{\rm ID} + B_{\rm CSI})\$ because the polling is done for a successful feedback case and for an unsuccessful feedback case to determine the CSI.
The CB feedback protocol in [6] fixes the feedback attempts to the number of feedback minislots.

The proposed feedback protocol outperforms the CB feedback protocol in [6] because to maximize the sum-rate capacity, the proposed feedback protocol controls multiple parameters such as thresholds, random access probabilities, and the number of feedback minislots.

Since the computation of the SMEEs becomes infeasible for long simple error events and the union bound may not converge as the number of SMEEs is increased (the bound may be larger than one for a particular fading realization [3]), a tight approximation to the union bound (called expurgated union bound) is obtained by considering a few most dominant SMEEs specified by a set \${\cal S}\$.

The expurgated union bound, together with a modified bounding technique and the limiting before averaging technique, was applied in [3] to evaluate the expurgated union bound on FER using the SMEEs for Rayleigh fading.
Good accuracy is achieved if the set \${\cal S}\$ contains all SMEEs with a few distinct (not necessarily the smallest) product measures [3].

context.text: Blind equalization of a multiple-input–multiple-output (MIMO) finite-impulse-response (FIR) channel is an important problem arising from a wide range of applications [1]–[2][3].

Since the windows of stationarity in practical data are relatively short, second-order statistics (SOS) tends to be more reliable than HOS [2]. in addition, SOS methods have lower computation cost than HOS methods [7].

One of the key steps of blind channel equalization using SOS is to identify (or estimate) the channel. for a MIMO FIR channel that is irreducible, column reduced, and driven by colored signals, blind channel identification can be achieved using the method in [2] and [3].

Moreover, if the source signals have sufficiently diverse power spectra, the method called blind identification via decorrelating subchannels (BIDS-2) [3], as well as its modified version in [2], can uniquely identify a MIMO FIR channel that is nonirreducible.
However, [2], [3], and [7] do not show how to recover the source signals after the nonirreducible (and possibly noncolumn reduced) channel is identified.

Our approach can be combined with the blind channel identification methods in [2], [3], and [7] to perform blind equalization of nonirreducible channels only using the SOS of the observed signals. in contrast, the existing methods on blind equalization of nonirreducible channels in [8] use the HOS of the observed signals and require the source signals to be temporally independent identically distributed and have the same constant modulus.

The passenger demand is completely satisfied.


•
The average number of transfers from one route to another is as small as possible.


•
The average journey time is as small as possible.

context.text: Among the other optimizers using Differential Evolution (DE) [10] in multiobjective optimization [11] the DEMO algorithm is using DE for the candidate solution creation.
Differential Evolution (DE) [27], [10] is a floating-point encoding evolutionary algorithm for global optimization over continuous spaces [28], [29], which can also work with discrete variables.
It was proposed by Storn and Price [10] and since then it has been modified and extended several times with new versions being proposed.

One of the most popular DE mutation strategy is ‘rand/1/bin’ [28], [10]: where the indexes \$r_{1}, r_{2}, r_{3}\$ represent the random and mutually different integers generated within the range \$[1, NP]\$ and also different from index \$i.
Another DE strategy is ‘best/1/bin’ [28], [10]: where \$\vec{x}_{b{e}st, G}\$ denotes the best evaluated vector in generation \$G\$.
The original DE algorithm is well described in literature [28], [10], and therefore, we will skip detailed description of the whole DE algorithm.

Recombination process is taken from the strategy ‘rand/1/bin’ used in the original DEMO [7] or the original DE [10], and the adapted \$CR_{i, G+1}\$ is used to create a modified candidate \$u_{i, j, G+1}\$ by binary crossover: where \$j \in
[1, D]\$ denotes the j-th search parameter, \$ra nd(0, 1)\in [0,1]\$ denotes a uniformly distributed random number, and \$j_{rand}\$ denotes an uniform randomly chosen index of the search parameter, which is always exchanged.

Wei and Jensen [9] proposed a GA-based motif searching tool named as GAME, which utilizes a posterior distribution score as a fitness function to evolve motifs.
Performance evaluation and comparisons were carried out by running additional programs GAME [9], GALF-P [21], MEME [6], MDScan [14] and AlignACE [23].

The existing fitness functions in solving this domain problem can be categorized into four types: statistical metrics [9], information theory based metrics [21], match-count based metrics [35], and combination type metrics and variations [22].
One method is the winners-take-all rule and another is the tournament method [9].
Tournament method [9] randomly picks out a pair and retains the one with better fitness value.
Eight benchmark datasets used in [9] were employed to evaluate the performance of our proposed GAPK.
The reasons to employ these datasets are: (i) They have been used in two recently proposed GA-based motif discovery algorithms [9] and [21].
In [9] and [21], they predict a k-mer as a true positive (TP) binding site if it has three base pairs overlap with the known binding sites.

To evaluate the performance of our proposed GAPK, we compared it with three commonly used motif discovery tools: MEME (Expectation Maximization) [6], MDScan (Exhaustive Enumeration) [14] and AlignACE (Gibbs Sampling) [23], and also two recently proposed genetic algorithm approaches, GAME [9] and GALF-P [21].

context.text: The deterioration of the performance of evolutionary algorithms (EAs) with increasing number of objectives has already been identified and reported in literature [7], [1], [13], [22].
Guided by this notion, dimensionality reduction procedures [7] (linear) and [19](nonlinear) were introduced in the domain of evolutionary multi-objective optimization (EMO).

To set the context for the ideas being proposed in this paper, the earlier work on dimensionality reduction using principal component based analysis [7], [19] including the formulation of constrained many-objective optimization problems, is summarized in the sections below.

Given the dearth of scalable many-objective test problems on the one hand and the need for a comprehensive test-suite for evaluation of the dimensionality reduction procedures, the existing DTLZ5 problems [8] were generalized in [7] and referred as DTLZ5-\$(I, M)\$.

While the formulation of the objectives remains the same as before (Equqtion 1), DTLZ5-\$(I, M)\$ problems differ from the original, at two fronts:
1)in the definition of the parameter \$\theta_{i}\$, given by Equqtion 2.

Also [15] tries to reduce search space through considering only vertices of obstacles and a similar method for simplifying search space is proposed in [14] by considering only corners of an obstacle as the whole obstacle.
Existing methods are cell based in which the environment is divided into a 2D matrix and each cell is colored black if it is occupied by obstacle or white if it is a free space [10], [11], [14].
This purely random population causes the convergence rate to be slow, thus we may find a suitable path in higher generations [14], [15].

In our simulations both quality and running time are discussed and we compare our method with [14] as a GA based method and VVc(c), [4], as a computational geometry based algorithm that finds the shortest and highest quality path.
Figure 8 through Figure 10 show the path generated by our method, VVc(c)and [14].
Parts (c) and (d) show the path generated by [14] in such form that the former has the same input parameters as ours and the latter has improved parameters as in Table 2 (right column).
On the other hand, [14] builds a poor quality path which has a lot of jerky movements with same input parameters as ours.
To improve the quality of path and to achieve a good one in [14], number of generations and children are increased.
The execution time for [14] consists of dilation which use cell based method and the evolutionary process.
The running time for [14] is the longest since it uses high number of generations and population size.
Also [14] takes long time to find a good quality path due to large number of generations, but our method clearly overcome them in much less time.

(MKP Dominance Criterion): Let \$A\$ and \$B\$ be two assignments that are feasible with respect to capacity \$c.\ A\$ dominates \$B\$ if \$B\$ can be partitioned into \$i\$ subsets \$B_{1}, \ldots, B_{i}\$ such that each subset \$B_{k}\$ is mapped one-to-one to (but not necessarily onto) \$a_{k}\$, an element of \$A\$, and for all \$k\leq i\$ (1) the weight of \$a_{k}\$ is greater than or equal the sum of the item weights of the items in \$B_{k}\$, and (2) the profit of item \$a_{k}\$ is greater than or equal to the sum of the profits of the items in \$B_{k}\$ - [6].

context.text: Recently, Whiteson and Stone [19] introduced an on-line neuroevolution approach inspired to the action-selection strategy used by temporal difference learning to deal with the exploration/exploitation dilemma.
This type of problem, not considered in [19], is interesting in the computer games domain as it is related to the more general issue of developing an adaptive game AI.
The on-line neuroevolution approach used in this paper has been introduced by Whiteson and Stone in [19] to solve stochastic problems taken from the reinforcement learning literature.
In his work he proposed a fitness propagation mechanism to deal with the stochasticity of the fitness instead of averaging the results of several evaluations as done in [19] and in this paper.
Then, we introduce the on-line evolutionary computation framework proposed by Whiteson and Stone [19] that we applied in combination with NEAT in this work.
However, a comprehensive introduction to these topics is behind the scope of this paper, thus we refer the interested reader to [13], [19].
In [19] Whiteson and Stone proposed to borrow from the temporal difference (TD) learning the action-selection mechanism and to exploit it for on-line evolutionary computation.

In this work we focus on two different action-selection mechanism widely used in the TD literature and, following what done in [19], we show how they can be used as evaluation strategies in on-line evolutionary computation.
Concerning the termination criteria, Whiteson and Stone in [19] set a constant number of evaluations to be performed in each generation.
However, such a criteria leads to poor exploration/exploitation balancing capabilities [19].

When it comes to applying it to evolutionary computation, the probability of selecting an individual \$p\$ in the population is computed as [19]
 where \$f(p)\$ is the current fitness of \$p, P\$ is the population and \$\tau\$ is a parameter to control the exploration/exploitation balancing.

Concerning the termination criteria, we used the same one proposed in [19], that is a constant number of evaluation computed as where \$\vert P\vert\$ is the size of the population and \$\theta_{eval}\$ is a control parameter.

The results obtained suggest that, as already discussed in [19], the off-line evaluation strategy is outperformed by the on-line evaluation strategies during the learning process because it is not able to deal effectively with the exploration/exploitation trade-off.
It is interesting to point out that our results do not suggest that the softmax is better than \$\varepsilon\$ -greedy as found by Whiteson and Stone [19].

By the way, the \$\varepsilon\$ -greedy evaluation strategy used in this work is substantially different from the one introduced in [19]: the number of evaluations is not fixed for each generation (as happens in the off-line and softmax strategies) but it is dynamically computed in order to guarantee that a fixed number of evaluations are assigned to the best solution found in each generation.
In this work we applied NEAT to TORCS, following the on-line neuroevolution approach introduced in [19].
Our results show that, using the evaluation strategies proposed in [19], it is possible to improve effectively the on-line performance of NEAT.
